title: How to Make Wooden Spike Throwers for Target Practice

steps.headline: Cut a wooden dowel into two equal lengths.
steps.description: A length of 6-8 inches (15.24cm x 20.32cm) is recommended.

steps.headline: Sharpen the ends in a pencil sharpener if you have one available, otherwise you can whittle the ends to points with a sharp knife.
Cut a notch in the middle of each spike with a hobby saw or serrated kitchen knife.
steps.description: The notches must be as wide as the spike and cut halfway through the width of the wood.

steps.headline: Use a small amount of wood glue to secure the spikes together, forming an "X" shape.
Allow the glue to dry for around 5 to 10 minutes.
steps.description: Once dried, find an old shoelace or other cord-like material to wrap the spike thrower together. Wrap the lace around the center of the X once, leaving about 2 inches (5cm) of length.

steps.headline: Wrap the lace around the X crosswise and tie the ends together in a double knot.
steps.description: Using a lighter, burn the ends together. Allow them to cool for a couple of seconds and press them tight with your finger.

steps.headline: Make a target.
steps.description: Targets can be made out of anything that the wood will pierce. For example, you could use a paper grocery bag and fill it up with Styrofoam. A large piece of Styrofoam insulation would make an excellent target as well; a great way to reuse old packaging.

steps.headline: Aim at the target and have fun!
